content.description: It's a one-move wonder, for sure. Start on the chicken neck and go right hand to a nice rail, or make the big boy move and go left hand to the top. The top out is a little tricky.
content.location: This is the small, low boulder sitting in the shadow of Forte.

content.description:
Several jugs lead you over the ledge and up the crack to the top.

Highball.
content.protection: Pads, probably two with the uneven, high landing.
content.location: On the same boulder as the V10 Forte, walk around the left on the main face. It is the obvious crack that ends in a notch at the top.

content.description: Just as cool as the sit. Start to the left of the ten on two high jugs. Follow the slabby face up and right to the nice-sized flake on Forte and make the jump.
content.location: To the left of Forte should be a pair of juggish holds about neck high. Follow this up and right to the last move of Forte.

content.description:
An almost historic, sharp, highball masterpiece and, I'd say, one of the best climbs in all of the highcountry. This amazing problem can probably be done many, many different ways, however all are probably around v10 and all make for a great climb.

Sit start on an obvious undercling at the base of the rock and bump a right hand onto the sloper edge leading up. left hand way out left to a sharp little crimper, bump the heel up and bring a right hand into the next high, juggy undercling. Re-arage feet, match and bring a right hand up into the good right hand edge on the mini-lip. Bump out left into the worst hold I've ever tried to pull on, and then comes the variation and the crux. Find a way to move up into the good jug (I get a high left foot just below the lip and pop way up to the crimp right beside the jug), and finally commit to the best and scariest move in the field. Top out and take in the beauty.
content.location: The tall, obvious line in the middle of the front of the big boulder.
